channel.title: The negro American
channel.description:
A lecture series by professor Benjamin Quarles of Morgan State College, Baltimore, made in late 1967 in the Detroit Public Schools. The series covers one topic each week.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

item.title: The Life of the Slave, Part II
item.description: In this program, Professor Quarles notes the greater freedoms generally awarded slaves in urban areas in the South and considered a recent theory that slaves may have internalized white stereotypes of African Americans to the extent that they began to believe them.
item.dc:creator: WDTR (Radio station : Detroit, Mich.)
item.dc:subject: United States--History--19th century

item.title: Turn-of-the-Century Protest
item.description: This lecture describes African American political movements starting early in the 20th century, including the creation of the NAACP, Marcus Garvey's emphasis on black pride, and the American Negro Labor Congress founded by Communists in 1920.
item.dc:creator: WDTR (Radio station : Detroit, Mich.)
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: African Institutions & Slave Trade
item.description: This lecture covers recent research into pre-colonial Africa as well as the development of the slave trade during the commercial revolution of the fifteenth century.
item.dc:creator: WDTR (Radio station : Detroit, Mich.)
item.dc:subject: Slave trade--Africa--History

item.title: Reconstruction and the Negro
item.description: In this lecture, Professor Quarles discusses the Reconstruction and post-Civil War politics, including Congress' efforts through the 14th Amendment to exert control over southern states.
item.dc:creator: WDTR (Radio station : Detroit, Mich.)
item.dc:subject: United States. Congress--History--19th century

item.title: The Life of the Slave, Part I
item.description: Professor Quarles discusses the complex status system and roles among slave holders and slaves in the Antebellum South.
item.dc:creator: WDTR (Radio station : Detroit, Mich.)
item.dc:subject: United States--History--19th century

item.title: The Contemporary Scene
item.description: This program looks at the 20th century political pressures leading towards civil rights protections, the evolution of civil rights issues from the South to a primarily urban African American population, the new sense of urgency created by lingering myths--such as as the myth of white supremacy--and the crisis in the civil rights movement over some groups advocating Black separatism.
item.dc:creator: WDTR (Radio station : Detroit, Mich.)
item.dc:subject: United States--Race relations--History--20th century

item.title: Slavery in North American Colonies
item.description: In this program, Professor Quarles describes how Virginia created the pattern of bringing Africans, first as indentured servants and then as slaves, to the colonies.
item.dc:creator: WDTR (Radio station : Detroit, Mich.)
item.dc:subject: Virginia--History--Colonial period, ca. 1600-1775

item.title: The Negro and the Civil War
item.description: When the American Civil War broke out, it did not start out as an abolitionist war. A war always takes configurations and patterns that we never dream of at the beginning. This program describes how President Lincoln and Congress were inclined against prohibiting slavery. However, after war broke out in mid-April, 1861, Congress began to strike at the institution of slavery because that institution bolstered the South and the Southâ€™s war effort.
item.dc:creator: WDTR (Radio station : Detroit, Mich.)
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.title: The Negro in the Twentieth Century
item.description: In this lecture, Professor Quarles discusses 20th century developments, including Franklin D. Roosevelt's "philosophy of the forgotten man," the positive impact of New Deal policies and African American's movements toward the Democratic Party, the NAACP's flank attack on segregation before the Supreme Court on separate but equal accommodations, Brown vs. the Board of Education, the Congress of Racial Equality, and Dr. Martin Luther King's formation of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference.
item.dc:creator: WDTR (Radio station : Detroit, Mich.)
item.dc:subject: United States--Politics and government--20th century

item.title: Anti-Slavery and South's Reaction
item.description: This program covers the growth of the abolitionist movement--fueled in part by economic factors as well as anti-slavery poems and fiction like Uncle Tom's Cabin--and the South's reaction through the creation of a counter-ideology.
item.dc:creator: WDTR (Radio station : Detroit, Mich.)
item.dc:subject: United States--History--19th century

item.title: Slavery: Decline and Renewal
item.description: This lecture examines early opposition to slavery in the 1700s, three provisions in the Constitution supporting its continuation, and its revitalization in the South as an integral part of the cotton industry.
item.dc:creator: WDTR (Radio station : Detroit, Mich.)
item.dc:subject: United States--History--18th century

item.title: Why Study Negro History
item.description: Why then should we direct our special attention to the African American? What people have thought about the African American, what they have thought about his role in American history, has shaped their behavior toward him. Their attitude has operated to the disadvantage of the African American such as it has operated to the disadvantage of no other group in American life. And, therefore, there is that great justification for a reassessment of our grasp of the role historically of the African Americans.
item.dc:creator: WDTR (Radio station : Detroit, Mich.)
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Negro in the American Revolution
item.description: This lecture covers the participation of African Americans in the American Revolution, beginning with the the death of Crispus Attucks, the first American killed in the Boston Massacre in 1770.
item.dc:creator: WDTR (Radio station : Detroit, Mich.)
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.title: The Downturn
item.description: This program looks at the rise of African American leader, educator, and author Booker T. Washington, who stressed accommodation over the airing of grievances, and contrasted his philosophy with that of sociologist and historian W. E. B. Dubois, who considered Washington's approach a soft-pedaling of civil and political rights.
item.dc:creator: WDTR (Radio station : Detroit, Mich.)
item.dc:subject: Washington, Booker T., 1856-1915

item.title: The Abolitionist Crusade
item.description: This lecture looks at the abolitionist movement of the 1830s, which differed from most reform movements since the abolitionists and slaveholders lived in different parts of the country. This led to a sectionalism that survives to this day.
item.dc:creator: WDTR (Radio station : Detroit, Mich.)
item.dc:subject: United States--History--19th century
